awd_titl_txt: Quantum dynamics methods for fluctuating systems in quantum environments: Development and application
awd_abstract_narration:
Seogjoo J. Jang of Queens College, City University of New York, is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry for developing and applying quantum dynamics methods for fluctuating systems in quantum environments.  For example, think of a molecular substance, like sugar, dissolved in a glass of water.  One could think of the electrons in the sugar molecule as the quantum system and the vibrations of the atoms in the sugar molecule as the quantum environment.  The fluctuations are caused by the motions of the solvent molecules.  Because of the counter-intuitive nature of quantum mechanics, it can be difficult to predict or understand the behavior of quantum systems without elaborate calculations.  However, even after almost a century since the theory of quantum mechanics was founded, reliable quantum dynamics calculations beyond simple models and systems remain notoriously difficult to solve. Building on their earlier computational research, Professor Jang and coworkers are establishing systematic computational approaches appropriate for very large systems in realistic environments. Accurate descriptions of the dynamic behaviors of such quantum systems has significant implications for designing novel energy conversions, imaging, and information processing devices.  Applications of these methods can elucidate quantum effects that remain important in noisy environments and can help develop new kinds of novel quantum devices. Professor Jang is working on a book on molecular excitons, which are important for solar energy conversion and imaging, and a review article on quantum dynamics methods.  He is also dedicated to organizing conferences on cutting edge topics, and is developing new types of undergraduate level classes integrating experiments and computation.

Professor Jang's group is developing and applying theories and computational methods for the dynamics calculation of quantum systems subject to general time dependent fluctuations while interacting with quantum environments.  Accurate descriptions of the interplay of these two complicating factors has significant implications for long-range energy and charge transfer processes in complex molecular environments, and is one of central issues in quantum thermodynamics, information processing, and conductance. On one hand, this theory is pursued through master equation approaches, by combining the polaron transformation or modular coarse-graining with systematic higher order expansions.  On the other hand, path-integral based theories and simulation methods are generalized for fluctuating systems. These methods are then applied and tested for the dynamics of delocalized excitons in light harvesting complexes and nanotubes, and for proton or proton-coupled electron transfer reactions in dynamic molecular environments.  Outcomes of this research can elucidate spatio-temporal dynamics of delocalized excitons in complex environments and can provide key insights into the interplay between the effects of quantum environments and time dependent fluctuations in the dynamics of protons and loose electrons   Professor Jang is working on a book on the dynamics of molecular excitons and a comprehensive review article on quantum master and Fokker-Planck equations.   He continues organizing conferences and workshops on topical issues such as excitons, quantum information, machine learning, and chemical sensing, and is also designing new small group chemistry courses that can integrate experiments and computation/modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit 

Quantitative understanding and manipulation of quantum dynamical processes such as energy and charge transfer in packed molecular environments remains a great challenge because of the complexity of interactions and various competing factors involved at molecular level length and time scales.  There are well established theories providing key qualitative insights for these processes in simple cases, but they are often found to be insufficient for understanding key microscopic details of current experimental interest.  Approaches toward direct computational simulation are pursued by many researchers, but they still remain largely incomplete.  This project made a significant contribution to addressing this challenge by combining theory development with detailed computational modeling of experimental data and by developing advanced theories capable of describing more general processes in efficient manner.   

On one hand, detailed computational modeling and theoretical analysis elucidated an important quantum mechanical enhancement mechanism of resonance electronic energy transfer in dyads of energy donating and accepting molecules linked by bridge units.  The key factor that was newly identified and quantitively verified was that vibrational modes of intervening molecular bridge units can enhance the rate significantly. For other types of molecular assemblies that have significant implications for the development of new solar energy conversion or imaging devices, collaboration with experimental groups helped characterize and understand key experimental data that are important for enhancing their functionality.  

On the other hand, a general and efficient theory of quantum dynamics simulation of energy or charge carriers in complex environments was developed.  This extends the quantum master equation (QME) approach that allows explicit description of major quantum systems while treating the effects of environments collectively.  The new theory builds on a so called polaron transformed QME, which accounts for major environmental effects up to an infinite order and enables a more flexible and general description of the interaction between quantum systems and environmental degrees of freedom.  Simple theories that offer new insights were developed as well. For cases where the transition can be described as rate processes, new modifications of well know and widely used Fermi's golden rule (FGR) rate expressions were developed.  These rate expressions make it possible to model quantum rate processes where the standard FGR rate expression is not applicable due to singularity associated with sparse density of final states or due to time dependent fluctuations.  Application of these rate expressions help more accurate calculation of FGR based rates and offer physically clear account of the interplay of dynamic fluctuations and quantum bath.  

 

Broader Impacts  

Major outcomes of this research project can contribute to more advanced design of solar energy conversion, energy storage, and biological imaging devices.  Research outcome on model quantum memory device can help development of better quantum information processing.  Theory of olfaction, which was achieved as a byproduct of this research project, offers a general framework for understanding a broad class of olfactory sensing processes including the effects of odorant mixtures.    

Two books published by the PI made positive impacts on helping broader scientists and students.   One book,``Dynamics of Molecular Excitons," assists broader community of scientists to learn detailed theories and underlying assumptions of molecular excitons, which are major quantum carriers of electronic excited states in various materials. The other book, ``Quantum Mechanics for Chemistry," provides detailed derivations of important principles of modern quantum mechanical theories and their applications to molecular systems.   The PI also made significant contributions to the broader scientific community through organization of virtual workshops during COVID-19 lockdown on various topics of theoretical chemistry, Telluride workshop on molecular excitons, and organization of special topic issue of the Journal of Chemical Physics on “Excitons: Energetics and spatiotemporal dynamics.”  Articles in this special topic and the editorial highlighted major challenges in the exciton research and their implications for the development of practical technologies for new optoelectronic devices.
